item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Lubrication of Platter Motor Bearings
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), the DC motor was lubricated. This particular motor uses brushes and has simple sleeve bearings. To access the bearings for lubrication, the pulley and outer housing were removed. The pulley is attached to the shaft with glue, allowing for easy removal. After taking out two small screws, the housing can be opened and the motor taken out. Next, the black rubber vibration insulation boot was removed, revealing the circuit board connected to the brushes.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of Worn Keypad
item.description: I’m currently working on restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable and have reached the stage of addressing cosmetic details. A common issue with this model, as with approximately 90% of them, is a worn keypad. The original coating deteriorates over time due to exposure to skin oils and acids. This results in unsightly smudges, especially on units that have seen regular use. I recently acquired some refurbished keypads from a contact in Denmark to have on hand for my restoration projects.

item.title: Bang & Olufsen MMC Cartridge Protector: Dimensionally True Reproduction with Stereolithography
item.description: I recently decided to test out the clear resin (sometimes referred to as “maker juice”) on my Formlabs Form 1 printer. I chose to design a replica of a Multi Media Card (MMC) cartridge protector, as they always seem to go missing. While I own multiple MMC cartridges, I only had one remaining protector. As you can see in the images, the finished product is pretty good! The term “transparent” might be subjective, as the 3D-printed clear material doesn’t quite match the real thing.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of Sensor Arm Bulb with an LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable, the light bulb in the sensor arm, crucial for record detection, was replaced with a longer-lasting LED. To ensure compatibility with the turntable’s bulb detection circuit, which disables record detection if a bulb failure is detected, the LED assembly was designed to mimic the current draw of the original bulb. LEDs inherently use less current, so a parallel current path was added to the LED board to compensate.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Adjusting the Floating Chassis Height
item.description: After adjusting the main platter bearing in a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, you’ll need to set the height of the floating chassis. The goal is to make sure the aluminum surface of the platter is level with the surrounding aluminum panels. You can adjust the height by turning the nuts on the leaf springs that hold the chassis and provide vibration isolation. Using an 8 mm hex wrench is recommended.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of a Stuck RPM Relay with a Modern Encapsulated SMD Relay
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, the motor wouldn’t switch to 45 RPM. After changing the control panel lights, it became obvious that the 45 RPM button lit up the correct trimmer pot but the motor speed didn’t change. The issue was a faulty relay that was responsible for switching resistor networks within the Wien oscillator’s feedback loop to adjust the resonance frequency. Finding a replacement relay for vintage electronics can be tricky.

item.title: Beogram 4002/4004: Replacement of a Broken Cable Clamp/PCB Holder
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), a broken cable clamp/PCB holder presented an opportunity to test a replacement part file. A fellow Beogram enthusiast from New Zealand shared the file, and in return, received access to parts in my Shapeways store. Photos document the broken clamp, the 3D-printed replacement, and the final installation. The new clamp fits securely with the PCB, keeping the audio cable properly positioned. With the successful trial complete, the part was made available for purchase in my store for other B&O enthusiasts.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Awesome Refurbished Keypads in the House!
item.description: I received two refurbished Beogram 4002 keypads from Denmark today. My friend, who did the repainting, said the weather conditions were perfect for the job, and he was right! The picture shows how fantastic they look. He’s incredibly talented! The keypads look brand new, as if they were just made in 1975. He did a phenomenal job. I had sent him a worn-out keypad from a Beogram 4002 I recently restored, and he even found another one!

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Motor Video Published - Check It Out!
item.description: I’ve finished my Beogram DC motor restoration video due to high demand! This video will show you how to disassemble the motor and revitalize the Oilite brass bearings by infusing oil under a vacuum. If your Beogram’s RPM is inconsistent, this video is for you! Have a look:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a Plug-In Ready SMD LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of my Beogram 4002 (5513), I installed the latest iteration of my SMD LED light source for the tracking sensor. Previously, I designed a drop-in SMD LED assembly to replace the incandescent bulb fixture, which worked well. However, it still relied on the original, cumbersome tracking sensor sensitivity adjustment process. This process involves carefully positioning the light sensors relative to the light source, a task made difficult by the mechanism’s sensitivity and the adjustment mechanism’s coarseness.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the Detector Arm Light Bulb with a LED
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable, a replacement was needed for the detector arm light bulb. The previous repair attempt had left the assembly in poor condition, with damaged wiring and a misaligned photo cell. To find a suitable replacement, a well-preserved Beogram 4004 was used for comparison. Given the scarcity of original bulbs and the desire for a long-lasting solution, a 3mm LED was chosen as the replacement.

item.title: Beogram 4000/2/4: Update of Sensor Arm LED Assembly. No More Crumbly Flex-PCB Mess!
item.description: I recently redesigned the sensor arm LED assembly for Beogram 4000, 4002, and 4004 because the prior flexible PCB design was too difficult for some users to install. My new design utilizes a small, rigid PCB that fits perfectly within the bulb housing and includes an insert to ensure accurate LED placement. This ensures the LED sits roughly where the original lightbulb filament was positioned. This image displays the new components:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Keyboard Repair - Detached Backstops
item.description: Following the AC motor hood restoration on a Beogram 4002 (5503), the next cosmetic issue addressed was the loose keypad backstops. Some keys were protruding and functioned erratically, requiring multiple presses. Upon removing the keypad and its PCB, it was discovered that several plastic backstops had detached. A previous attempt to reattach them using double-sided tape proved unsuccessful, causing an uneven keypad surface. The remaining backstops were easily removed, but precisely reattaching them posed a challenge.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Conversion of the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb to an LED and Adjustment of the Sensor
item.description: I began repairing a Beogram 4002 turntable that I purchased from Craigslist a year ago. I saw it as a good warm-up project before tackling the restoration of my prized Beogram 6000 4-Channel turntable. When I plugged in the Beogram 4002, hoping for the best but prepared for potential issues, nothing happened except for the complete absence of tracking. The tonearm wouldn’t lower, and there were signs of previous repair attempts.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of a Seized Solenoid to Tonearm Linkage
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I got from the UK had a seized linkage connecting the solenoid mechanism and tonearm. To lubricate this linkage, I had to disassemble the sensor arm assembly and remove it. Further inspection showed that the linkage’s rotating pin was stuck and had detached from its press-fit socket within the sensor arm base. I’ve created a video illustrating the problem and the repair process:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Installation of a LED in the Sensor Arm and Adjustment of the Detection Circuit
item.description: The last incandescent bulb in the Beogram 4002 (5523) being restored was located in the sensor arm. The sensor compartment, with the original bulb, was removed from the arm. A comparison of the original bulb and the replacement LED assembly is shown. The flexible PCB design allows the LED board to be folded and fitted into the compartment. The installed LED emits a warm white light, providing enough red photons to illuminate the red B&O logo on the arm’s front.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of the Sensor Arm Bulb with a LED Assembly
item.description: Following the replacement of the damaged MMC cartridge mount in the Beogram 4000 restoration, the next step was to switch out the last incandescent bulb with an LED replacement. The image displays the bulb housing removed from the sensor arm. The underside of the small PCB and its wiring are shown here: Constructed on a flexible printed circuit board, the LED module is designed to mimic the energy consumption of the original light bulb, preventing any issues with the Beogram’s control system (which verifies if the bulb is working).

item.title: Beogram 4000 Packaging for Shipping: An Update on How to Secure the Carriage
item.description: This article outlines a packaging update for the Beogram 4000, 4002, and 4004 turntables. Instead of taping the arm cover to the platter, the author now advises using an M3 screw to secure the carriage directly to the chassis. This change is due to the risk of damaging the arm cover’s labeling with tape during shipping. While the author previously suggested using paper to protect the lettering, damage continued to occur.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Signal Path between DIN5 Plug and Cartridge, Plug Replacement
item.description: I recently decided to update my Beogram 4002 turntable for the 21st century. While it was functional, the DIN 5 plug was noticeably worn and corroded. To address this, I swapped it out with a modern, high-quality Neutrik AG Rean NYS 322G plug featuring gold-plated pins, aiming for a reliable, long-lasting connection with my Beomaster 6000’s auxiliary input. The old plug was in rough shape, leaving me curious about its past.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the Detector Arm Light Bulb, Discussion of the Circuit and Relevant Oscilloscope Traces
item.description: A newly acquired Beogram 4002 turntable required a light bulb replacement in its detector arm. Despite the straightforward nature of the bulb replacement, positioning it correctly to ensure proper functionality can be challenging. A video documenting the process illustrates the installation steps, the adjustment of the bulb’s position, and relevant circuit components. Additionally, it showcases oscilloscope readings from a functioning detector setup. High-resolution images provide further insights from the oscilloscope:

item.title: Beo4 Enabled Commander Remote Control: Seamless Integration of Beogram 4002 or 4004 with More Recent B&O Systems
item.description: Dirk, a Beolover from Berlin, recently reached out about controlling his Beogram 4004 turntable with a Beo4 remote. He wanted to seamlessly integrate the turntable with his existing Beosound 9000 system. I found his idea intriguing and decided to modify the Beolover Commander remote to make it compatible. This involved adding a 455kHz IR receiver for Beo4 communication and deciphering the Beo4’s code system to rewrite the Commander’s firmware accordingly.
